ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the major trends in modern French literature, read 10 novels, and learned about 10 of the most influential French writers of the 19th and 20th centuries.
I learned a huge amount about the modern French novel, French literature, and the conventions and traditions that have been formed and broken in the French literary canon.
I learned about French literature, French culture, and literary analysis.
Great readings from 19th and 20th century French novels. You'll get to learn about history, how to read literature, and literary theory from two fun professors
Great books, must-take
You learn about French politics, literature, and writing. Brilliant course.
Critical thinking and reading, concise and persuasive writing - argument building
How to structure papers
The most important French novels and novelists of the 19th and 20th centuries

A wonderful understanding of the evolution and nature of the Modern French Novel, with aspects of history/culture treated as lenses through which to read some famous and beautiful texts. I became a better writer and better versed in French literary culture.

I learned about the historical context behind the novels we read, and about how the French literary tradition evolved through the ages. I also developed my close reading skills and improved my ability to write analytical essays.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: I loved that the main homework was just to read the novels. There were no other readings. I enjoyed most of the novels, especially The Red and The Black and The Lover. Professors Samuels and Kaplan gave very entertaining and engaging lectures on the historical context, writers, and trends we needed to know to contextualize the books. I was always excited to attend the Zoom class.

Weaknesses: Some books were a bit boring, but after watching the lectures I understood why they were significant.
This is an AMAZING class. I cannot think of a single way it can be improved.

Strengths: great reading list, professors, TFs
Weaknesses: not really any! (I'd say that staying on top of the reading throughout the semester was the greatest challenge, but that's not a weakness of the course)
Good books and good lectures.
This an incredibly engaging course that tackles numerous eras of literature through excellent novels everyone should read.
Incredibly engaging lecture and seminar with lovely discussion
I think the second half of the course went by very fast

Strengths: interesting books and historical themes
Weaknesses: lecture could prepare students a bit better to do close reading important for the exam
Terrific all-round - I have no feedback!

I loved the selection of books that we read, and I thought that lectures provided just enough insight to add to our reading experience while still giving us the opportunity to develop our own ideas. In terms of weaknesses, I wish the first two essay prompts for the writing section had been broader. I understand the motivation behind making us (1) compare two novels and (2) respond to specific guiding questions about the novels, but I found having to do both at the same time to be too restrictive. I think it would be better to ask students to do one or the other, rather than conform to both guidelines at once.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It worked fine with a simple Zoom lecture and Zoom section. Since the class was relatively small, we could even ask questions during the Zoom lecture using the chat.
I think this course ran with very little impact from COVID. The format of lectures suited Zoom.
N/A
All went well- lecture incredibly informative and thoughtful, section always enhanced lecture content
It was really helpful the main lectures were recorded
Not sure

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I don't know why this course isn't more popular! I really loved this class. Professor Samuel and Professor Kaplan are equally amazing, which I think is rare for a co-taught course. It was great to learn from their expertise in 19th and 20th century French novels respectively and also hear where their opinions differed. If you like to read novels, you will probably really enjoy this class. You get to learn about many different important writers including Balzac, Flaubert, Proust, Camus, and Duras. I did not feel like there was too much reading because most of it was enjoyable. The tests and essay were also very fair! Our first test had essay questions that focused on the themes and characters of the novels rather than memorizing material from lecture, which made things low-stress. Our second test was a longer take-home final with similar essay questions. This is an excellent humanities course, and I would recommend it to anyone regardless of major!

A thousand times yes. This course is amazing and highly accessible. There is the option to take the class fully in English, take it as a writing credit, and to take it with lectures in English and the readings, exams, paper and section in French. You can make of it what you like. The professors are such a dynamic duo, and the material we cover is fascinating - the kind of books that everyone should read. This is the best class I have taken at Yale.
Yes! A terrific course for people who are interested in learning just a little but about French literature, or just literature in general.

I'd highly recommend this class! It was one of my favorites at Yale (I'm a senior, STEM major). You'll read some interesting books (I wouldn't say they were may favorite books of all time, but as someone who did not know anything about French lit beforehand, this class was a great intro) and hear some insightful lectures from 2 fun, personable profs. The reading takes some time (I'm a slower reader, I think) and discipline, but I think it was worth it. Even better to take it Cr/D/F in your last semester (like me), so that you can just enjoy the reading and the lectures without too much stress
Yes. The readings were great and Maury and Alice are phenomenal lecturers -- each sentence they say is like poetry. Sections are meh but the good outweighs the bad.
Yes. I loved both professors, engaging class and an interesting entry point to French history and intellectual History

Yes if you like literature you have to explore the French canon with this class. Theres a lot of fun discussion through both a stylistic lens and a historical perspective, including realism and rising bourgeois values coming to dominate durimg and after the industrial revolution.
Absolutely. Take this course to remember why you like reading.
Yes
Yes, i really enjoyed it
For students interested in French literature
It was a great class, and Im glad I took it my final semester here. The class made me realize just what a privilege it is to be a Yalie and to learn from people like Profs. Kaplan and Samuels.

Absolutely take this course if you want a fun English/Literature style course! I had no interest in French literature before but genuinely loved almost all the novels we read. The teaching style was also great!

Yes! I am so grateful that I took this course because it introduced me to an entire literary tradition I wouldn't have otherwise encountered. I learned so much about literature and French culture, but also about life and what it means to be human. Reading these books kept me sane through everything that was going on this semester.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture and live virtual section.
Live virtual lecture that was recorded for students who had a schedule conflict, plus a weekly virtual seminar section.
Live virtual lecture and virtual seminar, but all were recorded.
Live virtual discussion section
N/A
Section
Non recorded small sessions
Virtual section
In addition to lecture, I also had a virtual discussion section once a week.
